lexUnit.name: inadequate.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: lacking the quality or quantity required; insufficient for a purpose.

sentence.text: ` Who is it , Dominic ? " came a voice from the sleazy depths of this small and totally inadequate council house .

In particular , it should have been apparent from an early stage that the railway would prove totally inadequate to deal with the demand generated in the Isle of Dogs , especially by the Canary Wharf project .

Today 's local area network systems are totally inadequate for such gigantic flows of information .
All the obvious expressions of sympathy were wholly inadequate .
The fog bank was unattainable and rather than surrender , Kennedy opened fire against both vessels with his antique and wholly inadequate guns .
Also the warning system was wholly inadequate .
The committee system is woefully inadequate .
The response to the problem has been variable , with excellent services being established in some areas and woefully inadequate facilities continuing in others .
The heating was woefully inadequate -- upstairs there were just pipes running round the rooms , and downstairs a few scattered radiators .

This now appears inadequate in its view of mathematics and of the learner .
The groundwater protection provisions are inadequate in that the powers granted to the Secretary of State in the Bill would enable him to weaken the protections specified in the schedule .
British films are too rarely good , not because of national character , but because of a production system that is inadequate to the task of generating a regular output of full-blooded films .
The thin gown of emerald green silk was quite inadequate to the task of concealing what lay beneath .
All paradigms will be inadequate to some extent as far as their match with nature is concerned .
I felt that any response I might make to this sad ending would be inadequate to the occasion .

EHOs said the domestic kitchen was completely inadequate for cooking on such a scale .
